awd_abstract_narration:
In this project the investigator and collaborators study a variety of questions in extremal and probabilistic combinatorics. While extremal combinatorics deals with the interplay between various properties of large discrete structures (e.g. graphs, hypergraphs, permutations, or sets of integers), probabilistic combinatorics deals with the typical relations between such properties. Both areas have grown tremendously in the past few decades both in depth and in breadth. They supplied many spectacular results that affected various other areas of mathematics, such as number theory, group theory, probability theory, information theory, and theoretical computer science. Furthermore, many key insights that were developed in order to solve some of the core questions in extremal combinatorics were later exported to other areas. A major goal of this project, besides answering the questions under study, is to develop new tools and techniques that will be applicable to other areas of discrete mathematics. The project provides research training opportunities for graduate students. 

The questions the investigator and his collaborators intend to study belong to some of the most actively studied topics in current extremal and probabilistic combinatorics, with many explicit and implicit analogies and connections between them. The first set of questions deals with classical extremal problems such as the Turan-number of bipartite graphs and the number of subsets of the first n integers not containing a solution to some fixed linear equations. The second set of problems deals with random matrices and addresses questions such as "what is the probability that a random symmetric matrix is singular?" and "how resilient is the rank of a typical matrix?" The third set of problems deals with anti-concentration inequalities and addresses questions such as "what is the probability of seeing a given number of edges when sampling a fixed number of vertices from a hypergraph?" The last set of problems deals with permutations and address the order of Stanley-Wilf limits and large deviation inequalities for random permutations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project mainly explored the rich intersection of combinatorics, probability, and linear algebra, leading to significant advancements in these fields. Throughout the award period, we developed innovative techniques in random matrices, random graphs, and spectral expanders, producing several high-impact results that have been published in top-tier journals.

Intellectual Merit:

The project yielded many important findings. Some of the key contributions include:

  • Multicolor Ramsey Numbers: In collaboration with David Conlon, we provided new lower bounds for multicolor Ramsey numbers (Advances in Mathematics). This results was featured in an article in Quanta Magazine
  • Odd subgraphs: Together with Michael Krivelevich, we proved that every graph GGG on nnn vertices, with no isolated vertices, contains an induced subgraph of linear size in which all degrees are odd. This result resolves a longstanding folklore conjecture in graph theory and was also featured in Quanta Magazine (Advances in Mathematics).
  • Random Matrices: We introduced simple proofs for the singularity of random symmetric matrices and sparse random matrices (Comptes Rendus. Mathématique and Combinatorics, Probability and Computing). We solved a conjecture regarding the singularity of the k-core of a random graph (Duke Mathematical Journal).  We studied the rank distribution and irreducibility of the characteristic polynomial of random symmetric matrices (Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society).
  • Reed-Solomon Codes: Alongside Matthew Kwan and Lisa Sauermann, we developed results related to list-decodability with large radii for Reed–Solomon codes, which was presented at FOCS 2022 and published in the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory.
  • Other results: Other major results include work on graph decompositions (Random Structures and Algorithms), Hamiltonicity of sparse pseudorandom graphs (Combinatorics, Probability and Computing, accepted), and more.

These findings have been influential, advancing the fields of extremal combinatorics, random matrix theory, and random graphs.

Broader Impacts:

In addition to advancing theoretical research, this project aimed to create bridges between the different fields. By publishing these results and actively engaging with people from the different communities, we’ve begun fostering new collaborations. Two of the project's major results were highlighted in Quanta Magazine, bringing these topics to a broader audience.

Furthermore, I have incorporated these findings into my teaching, developing materials that introduce some of me findings to undergraduate students. This includes new publicly avaiable lecture notes which I hope to edit into a book format soon and will make it avaiable (for free) on my website. 

I also expanded my outreach efforts, contributing to a 5th-grade math club, where I aim to inspire young students by showing them the exciting connections between mathematics and games. 

Conclusion:

This project has successfully achieved many of its goals, contributing novel techniques and insights to the studied fields.  The specific outcomes of the project are:

  1. David Conlon and Asaf Ferber, Lower bounds for multicolor Ramsey numbers, Advances in Mathematics 378, 107528.
  2. Asaf Ferber, Singularity of random symmetric matrices -- simple proof, Comptes Rendus. Math\'ematique 359 (6), 743--747.
  3. Asaf Ferber, Matthew Kwan, and Lisa Sauermann, Singularity of sparse random matrices: simple proofs, Combinatorics, Probability and Computing 31 (1), 21--28.
  4. Asaf Ferber, Matthew Kwan, and Lisa Sauermann, List-decodability with large radius for Reed--Solomon codes, FOCS 2022, and IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, Volume: 68, Issue: 6, 2022.
  5. Asaf Ferber, Vishesh Jain, Ashwin Sah, and Mehtaab Sawhney, Random symmetric matrices: rank distribution and irreducibility of the characteristic polynomial, Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, pp. 1--14. Cambridge University Press, 2022.
  6. Asaf Ferber, Matthew Kwan, Ashwin Sah, and Mehtaab Sawhney, Singularity of the k-core of a random graph, Duke Mathematical Journal 172, no. 7 (2023): 1293--1332.
  7. Asaf Ferber, Michael Krivelevich, Every graph contains a linearly sized induced subgraph with all degrees odd, Advances in Mathematics, 406 (2022): 108534.
  8. Asaf Ferber, Liam Hardiman, and Michael Krivelevich, On subgraphs with degrees of prescribed residues in the random graph, Random Structures and Algorithms, 63, no. 1 (2023): 192--214.
  9.  Asaf Ferber, Liam Hardiman, and Adva Mond, The number of $\ell$-hamiltonian cycles in dense hypergraphs, Combinatorica 43, no. 4 (2023): 665--680.
  10. Asaf Ferber, Matthew Kwan, Bhargav Narayanan, Ashwin Sah, and Mehtaab Sawhney, Friendly bisections of random graphs, Communications of the American Mathematical Society 2, no. 10 (2022): 380--416.
  11. Asaf Ferber, Ashwin Sah, Mehtaab Sawhney, and Yizhe Zhu, Sparse recovery properties of discrete random matrices, Combinatorics, Probability and Computing 32, no. 2 (2023): 316--325.
  12. Asaf Ferber, Jie Han, Dingjia Mao, and Roman Vershynin, Hamiltonicity of Sparse Pseudorandom Graphs, cpc, accepted.
  13. Asaf Ferber, Bryce~Frederickson, Dingjia Mao, Liana~Yepremyan, and Yizhe Zhu, Regular bipartite decompositions of pseudorandom graphs, submitted.
  14. Asaf Ferber, Marcelo Sales, and Mason Shurman, Covering Random Digraphs with Hamilton Cycles, submitted.
  15. Joszef Balogh, Anton Bernshteyn, Michelle Delcourt, Asaf Ferber, and Huy Tuan Pham, Sunflowers in set systems with small VC-dimension, submitted.
